newsitem.title: GERMANY: Lufthansa sees profit rebound in 97 - paper.
newsitem.headline: Lufthansa sees profit rebound in 97 - paper.

text.p: Deutsche Lufthansa AG expects profits to rebound in 1997 to around levels seen in 1995 after a drop of around ten percent in 1996, chief executive Juergen Weber said in an interview on Tuesday.
"Our aim is to reach the 1995 level. We are confident of achieving that," the German airline chief said in an interview in the Tuesday edition of the Financial Times.
In 1995 Lufthansa posted profit from ordinary activities of 756 million marks. The group has yet to report 1996 data, but has indicated that profits will be down around 10 percent.
The airline also said that 1996 revenues would be around five percent higher at around 21 billion marks.
Weber said that while productivity at Lufthansa had risen by around 50 percent since he took over as CEO six years ago, more still needed to be done.

Weber was confident that the group's proposed cost-cutting programme, which is seeking to save around 800 million marks by the end of the century, will be a success. "I am certain we can do this," Weber said.

Weber also said that he saw exciting prospects in the Asia-Pacific region and that Lufthansa was holding "promising talks" on developing alliances in Asia. He said China and India were countries where it wanted to expand business.
